entry.title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued April 1 at 8:50PM CDT until April 1 at 9:30PM CDT by NWS Springfield MO
entry.summary:
SVRSGF
The National Weather Service in Springfield has issued a
* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for... Cherokee County in southeastern Kansas...
* Until 930 PM CDT.
* At 850 PM CDT, a severe thunderstorm was located 8 miles southwest of Chetopa, moving northeast at 50 mph.
HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and quarter size hail.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Hail damage to vehicles is expected. Expect wind damage to roofs, siding, and trees.
* Locations impacted include... Baxter Springs, Columbus, Galena, Weir, Lowell, Sherman, Scammon, West Mineral, Treece, Roseland, Neutral, Melrose, Riverton, Lawton, Carona, Skidmore, Hallowell, Sherwin, Faulkner, and Stippville.
This includes Interstate 44 near mile marker 0.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Cherokee, KS

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued April 1 at 8:50PM CDT by NWS Lincoln IL
entry.summary:
ESFILX
This hydrologic outlook includes the following river in Illinois:
Sangamon River...
The following river information is based on future predicted rainfall. The exact amount, intensity, timing, and location of the rain that will occur is still uncertain. These outlook stages are provided to show what may be expected if the forecast precipitation occurs. Once there is more certainty about the river forecasts, a flood warning or statement will be issued if the threat materializes.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Cass, IL; Mason, IL; Piatt, IL

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued April 1 at 8:48PM CDT until April 1 at 11:00PM CDT by NWS Lincoln IL
entry.summary:
At 846 PM CDT, Doppler radar and automated rain gauges indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 1.5 and 2.5 inches of rain have fallen in an area from Assumption northeast to Arthur, with the heaviest amounts over far northern Shelby County. Additional rainfall amounts up to 1 inch are possible in the warned area, though rain rates will be diminishing by 10 pm.
HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms.
SOURCE...Radar and automated gauges.
IMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses as well as other poor drainage and low-lying areas.
Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Sullivan, Arthur, Moweaqua, Bethany, Lovington, Dalton City and Cadwell.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Macon, IL; Moultrie, IL; Shelby, IL

entry.title: Winter Storm Watch issued April 1 at 9:43PM EDT until April 5 at 8:00AM EDT by NWS Binghamton NY
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy snow possible. Total snow accumulations of 7 or more inches and ice accumulations of a light glaze is possible. Winds could gust as high as 40 mph.
* WHERE...Northern Oneida, Otsego and Delaware counties.
* WHEN...From Wednesday afternoon through Friday morning.
* IMPACTS...Plan on slippery road conditions. The hazardous conditions could impact the morning or evening commutes.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The highest elevations will have the best chance of freezing rain and heavy snow.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 1 at 8:43PM CDT until April 6 at 1:00AM CDT by NWS Lake Charles LA
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Louisiana...
Calcasieu River Near Glenmora
For the Calcasieu River...including Glenmora, Oakdale, Oberlin, Kinder, White Oak Park, Salt Water Barrier...Minor flooding is forecast.
Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.
The next statement will be issued Tuesday evening at 845 PM CDT.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Calcasieu River near Glenmora.
* WHEN...Until early Saturday morning.
* IMPACTS...At 12.0 feet, When the river is falling and the gauge reading is forecast to be near 12 feet, flooding of forested areas near the river will occur.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 7:45 PM CDT Monday the stage was 12.8 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 7:45 PM CDT Monday was 12.8 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 13.0 feet tomorrow morning. It will then fall below flood stage Friday evening. - Flood stage is 12.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Rapides, LA

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL EARLY SATURDAY MORNING

* WHEN...From Tuesday evening through Wednesday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Rain showers will give way to an accumulating wet / dense snow Tuesday evening into the overnight hours, resulting in sloppy / slippery conditions on area roadways. entry.summary:

* WHERE...Portions of central and west central Indiana, including the following counties, in central Indiana, Hendricks. In west central Indiana, Clay, Parke, Putnam, Vermillion and Vigo.
* WHEN...Until 1245 AM EDT.

entry.title: Rip Current Statement issued April 1 at 8:54PM AST until April 2 at 6:00AM AST by NWS San Juan PR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Life-threatening rip currents due to breaking waves between 7-9 feet.
* WHERE...Beaches along the western coastline of Puerto Rico, between Rincon and Aguada. For the high surf, the most vulnerable areas include Barrio Espinal in Aguada.
* WHEN...Until 6AM AST Tuesday Morning.
* IMPACTS...Rip currents that can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water where it becomes difficult to return to safety. High waves that can wash over jetties and sweep people and pets onto jagged rocks.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Rip currents can occur anywhere you have breaking waves, like sandy beaches on the open ocean, but can also occur where there are solid structures,like jetties and piers or even rocks jutting out into the ocean.

* WHERE...Santa Fe River at Three Rivers Estates.
* WHEN...From late Tuesday night until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 16.0 feet, Lowland flooding begins on SW Santa Fe Drive south of Santa Fe Road in Columbia County. At 16.3 feet, Florida Fish and Wildlife Commission begins enforcement of a no wake zone on the Santa Fe River from the unnamed island 1.5 miles downstream of the Wilson's Spring Boat Ramp to the confluence with the Suwannee River and on the Ichetucknee River upstream to the US 27 bridge. At 17.0 feet, Water begins to enter backyards of residences on Santa Fe Road in Columbia County and on River Run Road in Suwannee County. At 18.0 feet, Water begins to flood River Run Road in Suwannee County.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 7:00 PM EDT Monday the stage was 16.7 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage early Wednesday morning and continue rising to 17.7 feet Saturday evening. entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 1 at 4:37PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
A strong storm moving north into the Chukchi Sea on Wednesday will bring water levels up 2 to 3 feet along the coast from the starting Wednesday night. This will cause water to move on top of the ice near the coast in some areas. This could cause trails that cross ice near the coast to become inundated. This event will be similar what happened March 20, 2024.
Winter Storm Warnings, Watches and Advisories have been issued for many of these areas and are available on the Internet at weather.gov/afg.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Kivalina and Red Dog Dock; Lower Kobuk Valley; Baldwin Peninsula; Northern Seward Peninsula; Shishmaref

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 1 at 4:37PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:

This will cause water to move on top of the ice near the coast in some areas. This could cause trails that cross ice near the coast to become inundated. Ice could push onto the beach along south facing coast lines. This event will be similar what happened March 20, 2024.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 1 at 7:04PM CDT by NWS Green Bay WI
entry.summary:
Radar and surface observations indicate the west to east oriented band of snow that developed earlier has shifted to mainly along and south of highway 10 from south of Wisconsin Rapids, to Oshkosh and Manitowoc.
Thus far most of the snow accumulation has occurred on grassy surfaces, but some slush could still accumulate on untreated roads. Expect up to another inch of snow this evening before the snow diminishes. Visibility will be reduced down to a mile at times in pockets of heavier snow. If traveling this evening, especially along and south of highway 10, be prepared for varying road conditions and visibility. If you should encounter snow or slush covered roads, slow down and allow extra room between you and the car in front of you.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Waushara; Winnebago; Calumet; Manitowoc

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 1 at 3:34PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
A strong cold front will bring snow squalls, blowing snow, and reduced visibility along with much colder temperatures to the Interior from Fairbanks and the Tanana Valley south to the Alaska Range tonight and Tuesday.
1 to 3 inches of snow is expected from Fairbanks south to the Alaska Range Monday night into Tuesday. Northwest winds gusting over 30 mph will cause low visibility in blowing snow, and snow drifts will form. Temperatures will fall into the single digits tonight and then below zero Tuesday night. Northwest winds and blowing snow will reach Fairbanks, Nenana and Denali this evening and continue into Tuesday morning. The northwest winds and blowing snow will reach Delta Junction, Tok and the Eastern Alaska Range later tonight and early Tuesday morning and continue through the day Tuesday.

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued April 1 at 6:29PM CDT until April 1 at 9:30PM CDT by NWS Chicago IL
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.
* WHERE...A portion of northeast Illinois, including the following counties, Grundy, northern Kankakee and southern and eastern Will.
* WHEN...Until 930 PM CDT.
* IMPACTS...Creeks and streams may rise out of their banks. Area creeks and streams are already elevated, increasing the risk of flooding due to additional rainfall.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 629 PM CDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing very heavy rainfall. Doppler radar estimates suggest that up to 1 inch of rain has fallen over portions of Grundy County. An trained observer 3 miles north of Carbon Hill measured 0.60 inches of rain in just 15 minutes. - Additional rainfall amounts up to 1 inch are expected over the area. This additional rain will result in minor flooding. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Bourbonnais, Morris, Channahon, Manteno, Braidwood, Wilmington, Coal City, Peotone, Crete, University Park, Manhattan, Monee, Beecher, Diamond, Seneca, Elwood, Gardner, Lakewood Shores, Grant Park and Mazon. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Grundy, IL; Kankakee, IL; Will, IL

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 1 at 3:22PM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary: Bands of heavy snow showers will move north from Homer along the Sterling Highway over the next couple of hours. Snowfall rates of one to two inches per hour are possible with these snow showers, resulting 1 to 4 inches of snow accumulation, especially across the Homer Bluffs and Diamond Ridge. These bands will continue to lift toward Kenai by this evening as they weaken, resulting in less snow accumulation north of Ninilchik. Visibilities may be reduced to one quarter mile or less in heavy snow. Motorists are urged to slow down and use caution when driving through heavy snow showers.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Western Kenai Peninsula

cap:parameter.value: BANDS OF HEAVY SNOW ALONG THE STERLING HIGHWAY FROM NINILCHIK TO HOMER THIS AFTERNOON

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 1 at 3:50PM CDT by NWS Des Moines IA
entry.summary:
Patchy dense fog is developing over far southern Iowa as a strong storm and warm front is helping to focus moisture over the region. Visibility has dropped to a quarter mile to 1/2 mile at a few locations and the fog is expected to expand into the evening hours. Visibility will be around a quarter mile at times this evening.
If traveling over or into southern Iowa this evening, be on the lookout for rapidly changing visibility and use caution when lower visibility is encountered. Use low beam headlights and allow for extra time to reach your destination safely. The fog will persist until mid evening west of Interstate 35 and nearly until midnight east of Interstate 35.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Cass; Adair; Madison; Warren; Adams; Union; Clarke; Lucas; Monroe; Wapello; Taylor; Ringgold; Decatur; Wayne; Appanoose; Davis

cap:parameter.value: Patchy Dense Fog Expected Across the Area through Evening

Wabash River from Lafayette to Montezuma.
.Rainfall amounts of around two inches across much of central Indiana through Tuesday evening are expected to produce minor flooding along upper to middle parts of the Wabash basin. River flooding could begin by Tuesday afternoon at Lafayette and downstream locations thereafter. Locally higher rainfall amounts could produce more significant localized flooding. Persons with interests along area rivers should closely monitor the forecast as additional river flood warnings are possible further downstream on the Wabash as well as along other area rivers over the next couple of days.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Wabash River at Lafayette.
* WHEN...From Tuesday afternoon to late Saturday morning.
* IMPACTS...At 16.0 feet, Lowland flooding is in progress. Flood waters near SR 225 between Old SR 25 and Battleground. Warren CR 350 N near Black Rock Preserve and Tippecanoe CR 950 W in the Wabash Bottoms, Janssen Tract area may be impassable. Fort Ouiatenon grounds begin to flood. Flooding at the Grandville Public Access site.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 12:30 PM EDT Monday the stage was 4.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage early tomorrow afternoon to a crest of 15.7 feet Wednesday evening. It will then fall below flood stage late Friday evening. - Flood stage is 11.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Fountain, IN; Parke, IN; Tippecanoe, IN; Vermillion, IN; Warren, IN

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued April 1 at 11:31AM CDT by NWS Chicago IL
entry.summary:
ESFLOT
Isolated flooding of ditches, creeks, and poor drainage areas likely across northeastern Illinois and northwestern Indiana, generally near and south of I-80. Flash flooding of creeks, streams, roadways, and poor drainage areas possible along and south of US-24. Significant river rises and minor river flooding possible along the Iroquois, Kankakee, and Illinois rivers.
A swath of heavy rainfall occurred along the I-80 corridor overnight, with rainfall accumulations up to 2.5 inches. Elsewhere in northern Illinois and northwestern Indiana, rainfall accumulations up to 0.5 inches were widespread. Soil moisture is at least slightly elevated across the area, with near saturated soil moisture conditions likely extending from near I-80 southward to near US-24. Showers and thunderstorms are expected to develop later today, with multiple rounds of rainfall moving through northern and central Illinois and northwestern Indiana occurring through tomorrow night. Storm movement tomorrow favors the possibility of multiple thunderstorms moving over the same general areas, which increases the chance of heavy rainfall accumulations. Multiple swaths of rainfall of 1-2 inches are possible, with isolated accumulations up to 3 inches, especially south of US-24.
This outlook means that elevated water levels and potential impacts are possible, but not yet certain. Persons should closely monitor forecasts including the possibility of flood watches, warnings, and advisories.
No additional Hydrologic Outlooks are expected for this event, but other flood related products may be issued and/or updated over the next few days as the threat evolves.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Ford, IL; Grundy, IL; Iroquois, IL; Kankakee, IL; Kendall, IL; La Salle, IL; Livingston, IL; Will, IL; Benton, IN; Jasper, IN; Lake, IN; Newton, IN; Porter, IN

cap:parameter.value: Additional waves of rainfall may lead to flooding across portions of northern Illinois and northwestern Indiana

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 1 at 3:50AM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
A strong cold front will bring snow squalls, blowing snow, and reduced visibility along with much colder temperatures to the Interior from Fairbanks south to the Alaska Range tonight and Tuesday.
1 to 3 inches of snow is expected from Fairbanks south to the Alaska Range Monday night into Tuesday. Northwest winds gusting over 30 mph will cause low visibility in blowing snow, and snow drifts will form. Temperatures will fall into the single digits tonight and then below zero Tuesday night. Northwest winds and blowing snow will reach Fairbanks, Nenana and Denali this evening and continue into Tuesday morning. The northwest winds and blowing snow will reach Delta Junction, Tok and the Eastern Alaska Range later tonight and early Tuesday morning and continue through the day Tuesday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Upper Tanana Valley; Delta Junction; Upper Chena River Valley; Tanana Flats; Eielson AFB and Salcha; Goldstream Valley and Nenana Hills; Chatanika River Valley; Two Rivers; Fairbanks Metro Area; Nenana; Northern Denali Borough; Southern Denali Borough; Eastern Alaska Range North of Trims Camp; Eastern Alaska Range South of Trims Camp

entry.title: Rip Current Statement issued April 1 at 4:11AM CDT until April 2 at 1:00AM CDT by NWS Brownsville TX
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Dangerous south to north longshore currents with embedded rip currents expected.
* WHERE...Kenedy Island, Willacy Island and Cameron Island Counties.
* WHEN...Through late tonight.
* IMPACTS...Longshore currents and embedded rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The combination of southerly swell direction and building surf waves to 5 feet will push swimmers rapidly up the shoreline from south to north, especially at beaches of Cameron and Willacy County. A combination of longshore and rip currents are likely along Padre Island National Seashore in Kenedy County.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Kenedy Island; Willacy Island; Cameron Island

entry.title: Flood Warning issued March 31 at 9:47PM MST until April 3 at 8:00PM MST by NWS Phoenix AZ
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by rain and snowmelt.
* WHERE...Tonto Creek in Gila County
* WHEN...Until 800 PM MST Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Flooding of roads built into Tonto Creek. Low-water crossings such as A crossing, Bar X crossing, and Store crossing may not be passable.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 943 PM MST, gauge reports indicated rain and snowmelt causing rapid rises on Tonto Creek. Flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly in the warned area. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Tonto Basin. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
